sen.j: 御食国（みけつくに）は、日本古代から平安時代まで、贄（にえ）の貢進国、すなわち皇室・朝廷に海水産物を中心とした御食料（穀類以外の副食物）を貢いだと推定される国を指す言葉。
sen.e: Miketsukuni indicated the province that was assumed to supply food (secondary component of his or her diet except grain), mainly marine products, to the supply provinces of offering, namely Imperial family and Imperial court, from ancient Japan to the Heian period.

sen.j: 『万葉集』にある郷土礼讃の歌に散見され、『延喜式』の贄の貢進国の記述、平城京跡から出土した木簡の記述などから、若狭国・志摩国・淡路国などへの該当が推定されている。
sen.e: As it was seen many times in the poems of home admiration written in "Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves)," it seemed that Wakasa Province, Shima Province, and Awaji Province to be the appropriate Miketsukuni from the statement of the supply provinces of offering in "the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers)" and the statement on mokan (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written) that was discovered from the former site of Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara).

sen.j: 塩や鰒（アワビ）、海草などの海産物は、神事の際などに貢がれる神饌として古くから用いられた。

sen.j: 贄の貢ぎが史料として現れるのは、日本書紀の大化の改新の詔の其の四のところで、「凡その調の副物の塩と贄（にえ）とは、亦（また）郷土（くに）の出せるに随へ」とある。
sen.e: The supply of offering appeared as the historical materials in the section 4 of mikotonori (an Imperial edict) in the Taika Reform in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), and it said 'Usually, by-products of the cho (tributes) such as salt and offering, need to be followed by the local capacity.'

sen.e: According to "the Engishiki," in the article of Naizenshi (the office to manage dining for Imperial family and Imperial court) of the Department of the Imperial Household, there were items of 'Shokoku Koshin Onie (supply of offering from various provinces ' and 'Shokoku Koshin Mikuriya Onie (supply of offering to the kitchen from various provinces.'

sen.e: In these items, it defined for each province to supply assigned food directly to Naizenshi every month (shunryo), on New Year's day, on seasonal festival such as Ninamesai (the Harvest Festival)(setsuryo), and once a year (nenryo).

sen.j: 『延喜式』によると、若狭国は10日毎に「雑魚」、節日ごとに「雑鮮味物」、さらに年に一度「生鮭、ワカメ、モズク、ワサビ」を御贄として納めることが定められている。
sen.e: According to "the Engishiki," Wakasa Province was obligated to supply 'small fish' every ten days, 'sapid marine products' on every seasonal festival, and additionally 'raw salmon, seaweed, mozuku (alga-like seaweed), and wasabi' once a year as offering.

sen.j: 陸路より日数が掛かっており、運搬は船を使って平安京に運ばれたと考えられる。
sen.e: It took more than the land route, so it was considered that the delivery was made by a ship to Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto).
It took more than the land route, so it was considered that delivery was made by ship to Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto).

tit.e: The relationship with the Kashiwade clan
tit.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 膳氏（かしわでうじ）は皇室や朝廷の御饌（みけつ）を担当した伴造氏。
sen.e: The Kashiwade clan was the Tomonomiyatsuko clan who was responsible for meal for Imperial family and Imperial court.
The Kashiwade clan was the Tomonomiyatsuko clan who was responsible for supplying meals to the Imperial family and the Imperial court.
The Kashiwade clan was the Tomonomiyatsuko clan who was responsible for supplying meals to the Imperial family and the Imperial court.

sen.j: 後になり高橋氏と改めた。
sen.e: Renamed as the Takahashi clan later.
Renamed as the Takahashi clan later.
Renamed as the Takahashi clan later.

sen.j: 膳氏の出自を示した『高橋氏文』には、景行天皇が東国に行幸したおりに、安房国にて磐鹿六雁命（いわむつかりのみこと、膳氏の始祖とされる）が蛤（はまぐり）を捕り、天皇に料理をして献上したところ、天皇の子孫代まで御食（みけつ）を供するよう膳臣を授かったという記述がある。
sen.e: In "Takahashi uji bumi" where the place of the Kashiwade clan's origin was stated, it described that when Emperor Keiko visited the east province, Iwamutsukarinomikoto (known as the founder of the Kashiwade clan) in Awa Province caught clams, cooked and offered them to the Emperor, then he was offered to be Kashiwadenoomi (a leading figure who managed to supply food to the Emperor) to supply food down to the Emperor's posterity.
sen.cmt: 膳臣→Kashiwadenoomi (a leading figure who managed to supply food to the Emperor)大辞林 on the web【定訳不明】
sen.e: In "Takahashi uji bumi" where the place of the Kashiwade clan's origin was stated to be, it described that when Emperor Keiko visited the eastern province, Iwamutsukarinomikoto (known as the founder of the Kashiwade clan) in Awa Province, caught clams, cooked, and offered them to the Emperor, then he was offered to be Kashiwadenoomi (a leading figure who managed to supply food to the Emperor) to supply food to the Emperor.

In "Takahashi uji bumi" where the place of the Kashiwade clan's origin was stated to be, it described that when Emperor Keiko visited the eastern province, Iwamutsukarinomikoto (known as the founder of the Kashiwade clan) in Awa Province, caught clams, cooked, and offered them to the Emperor, then he was offered to be Kashiwadenoomi (a leading figure who managed to supply food to the Emperor) to supply food to the Emperor's posterity.

sen.j: 『高橋氏文』そのものが高橋氏の正統性を誇示する目的と考えられるため、全てを史実として受け入れることは困難である。
sen.e: "Takahashi uji bumi" itself was considered as to display the justice of the Takahashi clan, so it is difficult to accept everything as trueness.
"Takahashi uji bumi" itself was considered as an example of justice amongst the Takahashi clan, so it is difficult to accept everything as true.
"Takahashi uji bumi" itself was considered as an example of justice amongst the Takahashi clan, so it is difficult to accept everything as true.

sen.j: しかし、膳氏（高橋氏）が6世紀には膳職の伴造の地位につき、東国とのゆかりが深いとする説が有力である。
sen.e: However, it was the widely-accepted theory that the Kashiwade clan (the Takahashi clan) was assigned as zenshoku position of the Tomonomiyatsuko clan in the sixth century.
sen.cmt: 膳職→zenshoku (an officer who prepared meal for the Emperor and dining for Imperial court)大辞林 on the web 【定訳不明】
sen.e: However, it was a widely-accepted theory that the Kashiwade clan (Takahashi clan) was assigned the zenshoku position in the Tomonomiyatsuko clan during the sixth century.

However, it was a widely-accepted theory that the Kashiwade clan (Takahashi clan) was assigned the zenshoku position in the Tomonomiyatsuko clan during the sixth century and had close connection with the east provinces.
sen.cmt: and had close connection with the east provinces補足

sen.j: 『高橋氏文』には始祖の磐鹿六雁命（いわむつかりのみこと）が死去した際に、「稚桜部」（わかさくらべ）の号が送られたとの記述がある。
sen.e: "Takahashi uji bumi" described when Iwamutsukarinomikoto, the founder, died, the pen name of 'Wakasakurabe' was given.
"Takahashi uji bumi" described when Iwamutsukarinomikoto, the founder died, the pen name of 'Wakasakurabe' was given.
"Takahashi uji bumi" described when Iwamutsukarinomikoto, the founder died, the pen name of 'Wakasakurabe' was given.

sen.j: 若狭の地名は「稚桜部」が由来であるとする説があり、若狭国との関係も伺える。
sen.e: There is one theory that the geographical name of Wakasa came from 'Wakasakurabe,' and it revealed the relationship with Wakasa Province.
There is one theory that the geographical name of Wakasa came from 'Wakasakurabe,' and it revealed the relationship with Wakasa Province.
There is one theory that the geographical name of Wakasa came from 'Wakasakurabe,' and it revealed the relationship with Wakasa Province.

sen.j: 実際に福井県の膳部山は膳氏の名前が由来であると言われ、膳部山周囲に多数の前方後円墳が残る。
sen.e: It is said that the name of Mt. Zenbu (膳部山) in Fukui Prefecture came from the name of the Kashiwade clan (膳氏)(both has the same kanji character, 膳, with different readings), and many large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds remained around Mt. Zenbu.
sen.cmt: 同じ漢字「膳」が使われているという説明を追加しました。
sen.e: It is said that the name of Mt. Zenbu (膳部山) in Fukui Prefecture came from the name of the Kashiwade clan (膳氏)(both have the same kanji character, 膳, with different readings), and many large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds remain around Mt. Zenbu.

It is said that the name of Mt. Zenbu (膳部山) in Fukui Prefecture came from the name of the Kashiwade clan (膳氏) (both have the same kanji character, 膳, with different readings), and many large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds remain around Mt. Zenbu.

sen.j: このため、一部では膳氏は5世紀から6世紀には若狭周辺の支配者であったとする説が支持されている。
sen.e: For this reason, some supported the theory that the Kashiwade clan dominated Wakasa periphery from the fifth to the sixth century.
For this reason, some supported the theory that the Kashiwade clan dominated Wakasa periphery from the fifth to the sixth century.
For this reason, some supported the theory that the Kashiwade clan dominated Wakasa periphery from the fifth to the sixth century.

sen.j: また8世紀以降で高橋人足、高橋子老、高橋安雄の三名が若狭国の国司に任命されており、律令制成立以後は、内膳司が直接支配した地域である。
sen.e: In addition, Hitotari TAKAHASHI, Kooyu TAKAHASHI, and Yasuo TAKAHASHI were assigned as kokushi (provincial governors) of Wakasa Province after the eighth century, and Naizenshi directly dominated the province after the establishment of the Ritsuryo system.

In addition, Hitotari TAKAHASHI, Kooyu TAKAHASHI, and Yasuo TAKAHASHI were assigned as kokushi (provincial governors) of Wakasa Province after the eighth century, and Naizenshi directly dominated the province after the establishment of the Ritsuryo system.

In addition, Hitotari TAKAHASHI, Kooyu TAKAHASHI, and Yasuo TAKAHASHI were assigned as kokushi (provincial governors) of Wakasa Province after the eighth century, and Naizenshi directly dominated the province after the establishment of the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: しかし高橋氏文の史料批判の程度とともに、膳部山の記載は江戸時代に初めて登場し、膳氏と膳部山との関連性は低いと主張する説もある。
sen.e: However, with the level of the critics of the historical materials of Takahashi uji bumi, the description of Mt. Zenbu was first appeared in the Edo period, so some say the relationship between the Kashiwade clan and Mt. Zenbu was low.

sen.j: 一方、高橋氏は、幾つかの例外を除き、奈良時代から平安時代と長期にわたり志摩国の国司を世襲している。
sen.e: On the other hand, the Takahashi clan kept heredity of kokushi of Shima Province for a long time from the Nara period to the Heian period with some exceptions.
On the other hand, the Takahashi clan maintained the heredity of kokushi in Shima Province for a long time from the Nara period to the Heian period with some exceptions.
On the other hand, the Takahashi clan maintained the heredity of kokushi in Shima Province for a long time from the Nara period to the Heian period with some exceptions.

sen.j: 律令制下の一氏族による国司世襲は、きわめて例外的であった。
sen.e: It was extremely exceptional for one clan to keep heredity of kokushi under the Ritsuryo system.
It was extremely exceptional for one clan to maintain the heredity of kokushi under the Ritsuryo system.
It was extremely exceptional for one clan to maintain the heredity of kokushi under the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: 志摩国の国司と内膳司が兼任していたことは、志摩国が御贄を貢ぐことを義務付けられていた「御食国」だったことを示しているといえる。
sen.e: Kokushi was doubled as Naizenshi in Shima Province, and it indicated that the Shima Province was 'Miketsukuni' obligated to supply offering.
Kokushi doubled as Naizenshi in Shima Province, and it indicated that Shima Province was 'Miketsukuni' obligated to supply offerings.
Kokushi doubled as Naizenshi in Shima Province, and it indicated that Shima Province was 'Miketsukuni' obligated to supply offerings.

tit.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 阿曇氏（あずみうじ）は安曇氏とも記し、律令制の下で、高橋氏とともの内膳司の奉膳の職を世襲した。
sen.e: 阿曇氏(the Azumi clan) could also be written as 安曇氏, and kept heredity of the head position of Naizenshi with the Takahashi clan under the Ritsuryo system.
阿曇氏(the Azumi clan) could also be written as 安曇氏, maintained the heredity of the head position of Naizenshi with the Takahashi clan under the Ritsuryo system.
阿曇氏 (the Azumi clan) could also be written as 安曇氏, maintained the heredity of the head position of Naizenshi with the Takahashi clan under the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: 膳氏とは逆に瀬戸内海、壱岐など西国に影響力をもち、淡路島や小豆島などの海人、海部を支配していたとも言われる。
sen.e: Unlike the Kashiwade clan, the Azumi clan had influence on the west provinces such as Seto Inland Sea and Iki, and dominated male divers and amabe (people who served the Imperial court with the techniques of ocean navigation) in Awaji-shima Island and Shodo-shima Island.
sen.cmt: 海部→amabe (people who served the Imperial court with the techniques of ocean navigation)大辞林 on the web【定訳不明】
sen.e: Unlike the Kashiwade clan, the Azumi clan influenced on the western provinces such as; the Seto Inland Sea and Iki, and dominated male divers and amabe (people who served the Imperial court with their techniques of ocean navigation) in Awaji-shima Island and Shodo-shima Island.

Unlike the Kashiwade clan, the Azumi clan influenced on the western provinces such as; the Seto Inland Sea and Iki, and dominated male divers and amabe (people who served the Imperial court with their techniques of ocean navigation) in Awaji-shima Island and Shodo-shima Island.

sen.j: 一方で応神記に「海人が騒ぎをおこしたため、安曇連の祖大浜宿称を遣してこれを鎮撫し、海人の宰（みこともち）となる」というような内容もある。
sen.e: On the other hand, it was also described in Ojin ki that 'because the male divers caused a trouble, an ancestor of Azumi no muraji, OHAMA no Sukune, was sent to pacify it and became a head of male divers.'

On the other hand, it was also described in the Ojin ki that 'because male divers caused trouble, an ancestor of Azumi no muraji, OHAMA no Sukune, was sent to pacify them and became the head of male divers.'

sen.j: 若狭国や志摩国と膳氏との関係は、淡路国と阿曇氏との関係にも見て取れるという説も同様になされている。
sen.e: Some say that the relationship between Wakasa Province, Shima Province, and the Kashiwade clan could see with the relationship between Awaji Province and the Azumi clan.
Some say that the relationship between Wakasa Province, Shima Province, and the Kashiwade clan could be seen as the relationship between Awaji Province and the Azumi clan.
Some say that the relationship between Wakasa Province, Shima Province, and the Kashiwade clan could be seen as the relationship between Awaji Province and the Azumi clan.

sen.j: また768年に阿曇氏の阿曇石成が若狭国守を務めている。
sen.e: Also, AZUMI no Ishinari of the Azumi clan served as the head of kokushi in Wakasa Province.
Also, AZUMI no Ishinari of the Azumi clan served as the head of kokushi in Wakasa Province.
Also, AZUMI no Ishinari of the Azumi clan served as the head of kokushi in Wakasa Province in 768.

sen.j: これは高橋氏との権力争いとともに、道鏡との関連が指摘されている。
sen.e: It indicated the power struggle with the Takahashi clan and the relationship with Dokyo (a priest of Hosso Sect of Buddhism in the Nara period).

sen.j: 阿曇氏が海人を束ねる地位にあったことはすでに述べた。
sen.e: As previously stated, the Azumi clan was in the position to bring all the male divers together.

sen.j: また膳臣配下の膳大伴部も、志摩国の海人・海部を支配していたと考えられる。

sen.j: 万葉集の歌の中に「御食国」（「御食津国」、「御食都国」とも）が確認できる。
sen.e: Miketsukuni could be found in the poems in Manyoshu.

sen.j: それぞれ伊勢国（読み人不明）、志摩国（大伴）、淡路国（山部）など、その土地を賛美した歌となっている。
sen.e: Each poem admired the land of Ise Province (anonymous), Shima Province (written by OTOMO no Yakamochi), and Awaji Province (written by YAMABE no Akahito).
sen.cmt: 大伴・山部の名前を追加しました。

Each poem admired the land of Ise Province (anonymous), Shima Province (written by OTOMO no Yakamochi), and Awaji Province (written by YAMABE no Akahito).

sen.j: 天皇がその国・土地を賛美するということは、すなわち該当地域の支配を暗示したものである。
sen.e: When the emperor admired the province and the land, it implied the dominance of the appropriate areas.
When the emperor admired the province and the land, it implied dominance of the appropriate areas.
When the emperor admired the province and the land, it implied dominance of the appropriate areas.

sen.j: 贄を貢がせてこれを食べることで贄の産地たる河川・山・海の支配を儀式的に示したものと同様のものと考えられている。
sen.e: It was considered that by eating the supplied offering, it indicated a ritual indication of the dominance of rivers, mountains, and oceans where offering was produced.

tit.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 『若狭国』・『志摩国』・『淡路国』と万葉集にみる御食国への推定と、御食国が皇室・朝廷にとって特殊であるという説は、狩野久の研究によるところが大きい。
sen.e: "Wakasa Province," "Shima Province," and "Awaji Province," the estimation of Miketsukuni from the descriptions in Manyoshu, and the theory that Miketsukuni was special for Imperial family and Imperial court, were mostly due to the study by Hisashi KANO.

sen.j: 海産物が豊富にとれ、中央政府のあった畿内に物理的に近い
sen.e: The marine products were abundant, and kinai where there was the central government was geographically close.

sen.j: 膳氏（高橋氏）や阿曇氏（安曇氏）との関わりが深い
sen.e: The Kashiwade clan (the Takahashi clan) and Azumi clan had close relationships.

sen.j: しかし、平城京から発見されている木簡や『延喜式』で贄を納めることを義務付けられていた国は、信濃国、下野国など内陸で比較的畿内より遠い国もある。
sen.e: However, according to the mokan and "the Engishiki" discovered from Heijo-kyo, the provinces obligated to pay offering were sited in the inland areas such as Shinano Province and Shimotsuke Province, and those were relatively far from kinai.
